title: 111_s3238
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The tragic events of September 11, 2001, have forever changed the nation. Heroes from various government agencies responded to the attacks at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, taking heroic actions to save lives. The passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93 also showed bravery in preventing further casualties. The heroes of September 11, 2001, including government agencies, Pentagon employees, and the passengers of United Airlines Flight 93, took noble actions to prevent further casualties and ensure the safety of innocent Americans. Their sacrifices deserve recognition with an appropriate medal. SEC. 3. Fallen heroes of 9/11 to receive Congressional Medals. The President is authorized to award a "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal" to individuals and organizations in recognition of their sacrifices and to honor those who died on and after September 11, 2001. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 designs of medals for this purpose. The Secretary will strike 3 designs of medals to honor those who lost their lives in the 9/11 attacks at the World Trade Center, Flight 93, and the Pentagon. Consultation with the Secretary of Defense and other relevant parties will be done before finalizing the design. The Secretary will strike silver and gold medals to honor individuals who died as a direct result of the 9/11 terrorist attacks within the United States. Eligibility for the medal will be determined by the Secretary in consultation with other government officials. SEC. 4. DUPLICATE MEDALS.

The Secretary will create bronze duplicates of the medals for distribution to precinct houses, firehouses, and other duty stations where individuals who responded to the 9/11 attacks were assigned. These duplicates will be displayed in memory of those who perished.

SEC. 5. ESTABLISHMENT OF LISTS OF RECIPIENTS. Before the end of the 120-day period after the enactment of this Act, the Secretary will establish lists of eligible individuals to receive a medal under section 3(c)(1) and eligible recipients of a duplicate medal. Consultation with various organizations will be done to make determinations, and the lists established will be final. The Secretary will establish lists of eligible individuals and recipients for medals, which will be final and not subject to judicial review. If anyone becomes eligible, their name will be promptly added to the appropriate list. SEC. 6. The Secretary can sell duplicate bronze medals to cover costs. SEC. 7. Medals under this Act are national medals.
